intro: Paracyclea insularis, commonly known as the island moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean islands. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night, emitting a sweet fragrance to attract nocturnal pollinators. Its leaves are ovate and velvety, while its stems are covered in fine hairs. Paracyclea insularis thrives in humid, coastal environments and is often found growing in sandy soils near the shoreline.
